Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i thought the nullifiers are a hash of the data so without the unencrypted data you wouldnt be able to reverse any nullifier back to the original proof

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> I think you are correct @jl777c , but there are bits of metadata that can be woven together from different sources, some which are heuristics

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> yes, this just shows that if you need privacy, you need a 100% zaddr chain and NEVER leak your real zaddr

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> or a txid that is involving your main zaddr

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c so many of us have broken that rule, even just for documentation/marketing purposes, or in "real life". I always knew my paranoia was well-founded, I just needed to find the reason

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> just have a "hot" zaddr for such things and always z->z into the main zaddr to break any links

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c HushList protocol was always designed with this in mind

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> since 1.5yrs ago, my paranoia saves me

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> You never tell anybody your main zaddr for HushList, you give each new person an "introducer zaddr"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> So you can't do these linkage attacks

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Also, stopp the presses

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Nick Szabo liked one of my Tweets!!!!! My work today, is done

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> https://twitter.com/dukeleto/status/1161098620709548032

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> And to give credit where it's due, radix42 thought up "introducer zaddrs", I just ran with the concept

Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> we just got it working a few mins ago

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> #dev-nspv in KMD discord for more details

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> Nic

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> Do we need to do anye like thng

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> Anything

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <ITM> that actually awesome, means mobile version of hush is possible.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> And different from arrr which. Can't support nspv

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> libnspv is 100% C, has only libevent and libsodium as external dependencies

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> shouldnt be hard for someone to port this to mobile

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the html is actually all static html, no javascript

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> the C code is dynamically generating all the html based on current internal state

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> so the html template files can be tweaked however you want, $VARIABLE in the html are replaced with the dynamic data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> libnspv is fully aware of dPoW and marks txid that are notarized, it can even claim KMD rewards properly

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> i think it has a bit too much details for the non-tech users, but they can just ignore it and it is there for the advanced users

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> this is for taddr only, it has no ideas about zaddr. maybe it will have some display problems for txid with zaddr in it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> very young still, the gui was put together over the weekend

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @jl777c i am extremely impressed with your progress with nspv, even by jl777 standards, you went from nothing to 90% done in a matter of days, it seems

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> it has been about a month since i first got the idea for nSPV

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> first i hacked the komodo to have nSPV=1 mode

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> then added the nspv client to libbtc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> then satinder did all the html, i just did the $variable replace and a bit of page control flow

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> also, borrowed heavily from iguana, so the api processing and html server took a few hours instead of a few weeks just for that

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> as i said originally nSPV is very simple in what it has to do, so it allows a simple solution to be coded quickly. also blackjok3r helped with peer handling and making sure they are on the notarized chain

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <jl777c> but yes, even by my standards, this went from concept to GUI in record time as i took upon the gui part myself. i wanted something easy to use that is basically as secure as using cli without any layer of code added on top and certainly no javascript and most definitely no node.js

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> Would it be possible to have the encrypted message breakdown over a certain period of time?  Maybe even set by the sender?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @siaynoq great question and even better username

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> ðŸ˜‰

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> For deep reasons, the answer is No. The number 1 reason is: taking a screenshot

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> What do you mean by break down over time?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> And receiver gets plaintext, who can copy it to a text file or paste into an email

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> They mean "disappearing messages"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> self-destructing information

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> or encrypt it there?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <AkiraX> Maybe cryptoconditions?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @siaynoq it's highly encouraged to encrypt your memo field, for any vaguely sensitive data

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> which means the person receiving needs additional info to decrypt, but still doesn't self-destruct it

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> nice. just to make that user friendly is the hard part haha

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> The memo field is already encrypted, but that is just on the blockchain. When it hits your receivers wallet, they can do what they want with the plaintext

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> So it's like asking "Can I make an disappearing PGP-signed email?" and the reason, for deep reasons, is "No"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> got it.   Just trying to brainstorm the easiest way for common users to achieve that within the wallet

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @siaynoq what say the Fish Speakers?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> #metoo?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> lol

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> @siaynoq also, SilentDragon will support additional encryption of memo fields

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> NICE

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> such as "encrypt the memo field with this password"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and then the receiver needs the password to decrypt

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> it also means, you need a secure way to send that password to them

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> PERFECT.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> So it solves some problems while making others

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> I like that meaning described as "giving honor to those that speak with sincerity"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> You can also use memo fields to send passwords to future memo fields :exploding_ping:

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <siaynoq> super sweetness.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> Such as "I will send you half the password to zadd1 and half to zaddr2 and let's hope nobody has backdoored both different wallets that store those addresses!"

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrd-hush] <dukeleto> and various other complex schemes
